page.title: 04BUILDINGS AND SURROUNDINGS
page.content: There are few buildings in this area of large fields and woodland patches. The traditional building material is stone, which is used for houses, barns and field boundary walls. There are several small quarries which are no longer used and remain as waste land. Most dwellings are built of stone. These are the farmhouses and the former farm cottages. Sudeley Lodge is an early eighteenth century ashlar faced stone house with a hipped stone roof. These are also more modern buildings, one is a bungalow. Farm buildings are also built of modern materials such as concrete and corigated metal. Some dry stone walls survive and where they have fallen down, the gaps are patched with posts and wire. This type of fencing is also used to edge some fields.
